{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3479506,"name":"Noah","username":"Noahfrom6884","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/bcef8e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-11T22:57:14.420Z","cooked":"

We recently had a Pigeon 2.0 die on us, and when investigating why this happened, we found a possible flaw with the REV Mini Power Module that could cause components to malfunction and die invisibly over time.

Our Pigeon, right before it died, drew enough current from the MPM to drop the voltage on that wire to 1.79V from 12V. When investigating the possible reasons for why this happened, one of us measured if there was current running through ports without a fuse in them, which it turns out there was.

The status LED is connected internally to the main power input through a transistor, as well as the power output of the port next to it. The LED drive circuit presents a 300K ohm impedance to the 12V input. When there is no fuse or a broken fuse in a port, this circuit acts as a short, allowing power to still be drawn from main to a device in the port. For CAN devices, like the Pigeon 2.0, this is very bad, as the CANbus can act as a power source to the device, rather than the actual power wires, by forward biasing protection diodes from CANbus to input power. This can slowly kill any circuitry that has no protection from this.

image3024×4032 2.63 MB

(PCB of mini power module.)
image4284×4539 1.75 MB

(A simplified version of how the circuit is wired, assuming the LED itself is 300K ohm, rather than its circuit, which in this case is equivalent.)

Do any other teams know about this flaw? Are there alternative power sources that can break out one port on a PDH into many small ports?

TDLR/more general explanation: Mini Power Modules have 2 circuits that connect to the power outputs from the input, which can cause massive, but invisible issues if a fuse blows or is not installed to any connected components, due to how CANbus is wired internally.
